snippet: A federal appeals panel said an energy company founder had waited too long to file suit against Christie’s, the auction house, over a bottle of wine marked “1787 Branne-Mouton Th.J.”
abstract: Federal appeals panel in Manhattan says that William I Koch waited too long to file suit against Christie's, which sold him a $100,000 bottle of wine it falsely advertised as having belonged to Thomas Jefferson; panel rules that four-year statute of limitations began in 2000 when Koch received a report he had commissioned on the age of the wine, but he waited until 2005 to file the suit.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals panel said an energy company founder had waited too long to file suit against Christie’s, the auction house, over a bottle of wine marked “1787 Branne-Mouton Th.J.”

headline.seo: Court Rules Against Buyer of Wine Jefferson Supposedly Owned
headline.main: Even if ‘Rare’ Wine Was Too Young, Lawsuit Was Too Late, Court Says
headline.print_headline: Even if ‘Rare’ Wine Was Too Young, Lawsuit Was Too Late, Court Says
